Baraboo Appeals court rules state law bars tougher local tobacco laws
By Michael C. Buelow
Associated Press Writer ·
. MADISON, Wis. (AP) - Ruling in a Fond du Lac case, ao appeals court snid Wednesday that local governments may not enact laws sir- icter than state law to curb tobacco use by mismos.
The euy of Fond du Lac adopted an cisdinance in December 1993 that hatned self-service displays allow. ing peuple tu hay single packs of ci- garcties without merchant assistance.
Stale law prohibits the sale of ci- gactex lo people under age 18 aux regalates the placement and opera- sim of cigarelle vending machines.
In 1994, the city was sued hy sev- eral retailers who claimed that the address the problemn. But the appeals court held that-the- state law "includes a requirement city had overstepped its police power. when i. enacted .its. self -. that localities may only -adopt- service display ban because the xtate lohacco-related ordinances which 'strictly conform" to state law." already had regulations governing the sale and use uf tobacco ..
The state Court of Appeals said the case boiled down to: "Dnes the state legislation preempt the city's tabacco ordinance?"
The city claimed its ordinance was valid because it regulated sis- pects of tobacco distribution on which state regulations were silent.
It argued that other cities had suc- cessfully defended ordinances that controlled automobile noise polly- tions - car horns and broken mul- flerx -- because state cales did not
Court ruling Anti-smoking laws no stricter than slate
JAN 24 '96 14:19
MADISON, Wis. (AP) -- Ruling in a Fond du Lac case, an appeals court said Wednesday that local governments may not chaci laws str- icter than state law to curb fobacon use by minors.
"The city of Fond du Lac adkyyed an ordi- nance in December 1993 that banned sclf- service displays allowing peuple to buy single packs of cigarettes without merchant assistance.
State law prohibits the sale of cigarettes to people upder age 18 and regulates the place- ment and operation of cigarette vending machines.
In 1994. the city wax sued by several retail- erx whe claimed that the city had overstepped its pulice power when it enacted its self- service display han because the state already had regulations guverning the sale and use of
:
Stevens Point
Court says state bars local tobacco laws
. MADISON, Wis. (AP) - Fond du Lac went too far when It enacted local controls designed to keep minors from, buying cigarettes from vending machines, an appeals court has ruled."
The judges held that local governments may not enact laws stricter than state law when it comes to controlling sales of tobacco products. ..
Leaders of merchants' groups halled the decision as a victory for retall- ers.
State law prohibits the sale of cigarettes to people under age 18 and reg- ulates the placement and operation of cigarette vending machines.
Fond du Lac adopted an ordinance In December 1993 that banned self- service displays allowing people to buy single packs of cigarettes without merchant assistance.
M&M/TheBarkinGrp
"The overall depth of legislative curenige in the field of tobacco sales infanns use chut the 'striet confor- mity' language wax intended to stop local rulemaking wherever the state law was silent, not enable it." the ap- peale court ruled.
However, the court added that st- dies and evidence presented by the city regarding tough cigarette reg- ulations elsewhere showed that the city's regulation may be mure effec- tive al preventing teen-age smoking.
Partage
